videos.title: Welcome to Music With Meg!
videos.description:
Welcome to Music With Meg...!

Learn together in a fun, engaging and interactive videos!

Each week I will be teaching you all about music. Meet new musical instruments, learn new musical terms, and discover music both old and new!

In this new series, your child will learn the foundations of music, knowledge that they can carry throughout their musical journey. As well as exploring musical instruments, key skills and terminology, we will also look at the history of music, how instruments are made, and how music is created. 

So join me here, every week, while we discover the wonderful world of music.

videos.description:
To help me make more Music With Meg, please consider contributing:

Welcome to Music With Meg - Online music classes for children! Have fun while meeting new instruments, learning music theory and exploring the wonderful world of music!
Leave a tip on PayPal! paypal.me/learnmusicwithmeg

This week, we are introducing the violin... Learn the parts of the violin, how the violin is played, and listen to some famous violin music!

What do you want to see on next week's video? Let me know on:
Facebook - www.facebook.com/learnmusicwithmeg
Twitter - www.twitter.com/musicwithmegUK
Email - music@withmeg.com

Featured music:
Michael Jackson - Don't Stop Till You Get Enough
Carly Rae Jepson - Call Me Maybe
Vivaldi - Four Seasons (Spring) (recorded by John Harrison with the Wichita State University Chamber Players)

Musical terms from this episode:
PARTS OF THE VIOLIN -
Scroll (the very top of the violin)
Pegs (we use these to tune the violin)
Neck
Fingerboard (where we can move our fingers to change the note)
Bridge (holds the strings up)
Tailpiece
Chin rest (goes underneath your chin)
F-Holes (where the sound comes from!)
Strings (G, D, A, E)
Bow (made from wood and horse's hair)
Rosin (makes the bow sticky!)

WAYS OF PLAYING THE VIOLIN -
Legato (smooth)
Staccato (bouncy)
Col legno (turning the bow upside down and playing with the wooden part)
Tremolo (moving the bow really fast!)

MUSICAL TERMS FROM THIS EPISODE:

Parts of the accordion -
Bellows
Bass Buttons
Keyboard
Registers
Reeds

Other musical terms - 
Key Note (The main note in a chord - the note that tells us the KEY)
Chords (More than one note played at the same time)
Major (Generally known as a 'happy' chord)
Minor (Generally known as a 'sad' chord)
Dominant 7th (A jazzy chord - think Walking Bass/12-bar blues)
Diminished 7th (The 'UH-OH' chord! Used in scary movies!)

This week we're learning more about rhythm, by learning all of the note values! We will introduce Minims, Semi-breves and Semi-quavers, as well as Ties and Dotted notes.

Watch the US version here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Np-QMGGu6-Q
Watch Rhythm Level 1 here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WrEROwDoIcg

Email - music@withmeg.com

Musical Terms from this week:
Crotchet (1 beat / "quarter note")
Minim (2 beats / "half note")
Semibreve (4 beats / "whole note")
Quaver (1/2 beat / "eighth note")
Semi-quaver (1/4 beat / "Sixteenth note")
Tie (Combines the value of two notes)
Dot (Increases the value of the note by half)

videos.title: Rhythm Games: The Poison Rhythm Level 2!!
videos.description:
Welcome to Music With Meg - online music classes for children! Have fun while meeting new instruments, learning music theory and exploring the wonderful world of music!

To help me make more Music With Meg, please consider contributing:
Buy me a coffee on Ko-Fi:
www.ko-fi.com/musicwithmeg
Make a contribution via Paypal:
www.paypal.me/learnmusicwithmeg

Today we're playing a Rhythm game! Clap along with me, but watch out for the Poison Rhythm!
Today's game uses crotchets (quarter notes), quavers (eighth notes), semiquavers (sixteenth notes), minims (half notes), and crotchet and quaver rests! We'll also use syncopated rhythms and 3/4 and 4/4 time!

Poison Rhythm Level 1: https://youtu.be/s_wwttejEvo
Syncopated Rhythm: https://youtu.be/Vlbdu78FFhE

videos.title: Music With Meg is Back!
videos.description:
Happy New Year and a warm welcome to subscribers old and new!

Music With Meg returns in 2024 with plenty more videos on music theory, instruments, piano, violin, and more!

Leave a comment below letting me know what you'd like to see on Music With Meg this year.
And don't forget to Like, Subscribe, and find me on Instagram (@musicwithmegUK) for all the latest updates!

videos.title: How to Practice Your Instrument
videos.description:
Today we're looking at how to make the most of your practice session. The golden rule of practicing is: Practice often, practice focused!

We'll cover how to optimise your environment for the best practice, how to warm-up, and how to improve your playing by perfecting the tricky parts of your music.

Keep your eyes peeled for more practice tips coming soon, and leave me a comment below if you have any questions or tips of your own!

Visit my Ko-fi page for PDF practice resources: 
www.ko-fi.com/musicwithmeg

videos.title: Reading & Writing Intervals | Grade 5 Theory
videos.description:
Learn how to easily read and write Intervals above and below an octave!
We will cover how to identify Seconds, Thirds, Fourths, Fifths, Sixths and Sevenths, and how to tell if they are Perfect, Major, Minor, Augmented or Diminished. We'll also learn about Compound Intervals, and discover some easy tricks for writing intervals.

Support me on Ko-fi! ko-fi.com/musicwithmeg
Follow me on Instagram: @musicwithmegUK

Leave me a comment below if you have any questions!

videos.title: Writing Key Signatures | Super Speedy Theory
videos.description:
Discover how to write key signatures in Treble, Bass, Tenor and Alto clef! Essential for Grade 5 Theory and beyond. 

Find theory resources on Ko-fi! ko-fi.com/musicwithmeg
Follow me on Instagram: @musicwithmegUK

Leave me a comment below if you have any questions!

videos.title: Musical Cadences Explained
videos.description:
Cadences are made simple! In this video we will discover the two types of Finished Cadence: Perfect Cadence and Plagal Cadence, and the two types of Unfinished Cadence: Imperfect Cadence and Interrupted Cadence. You'll learn how to write and easily identify these cadences in music. Now all that's left is to practice!

Find theory resources on Ko-fi! ko-fi.com/musicwithmeg
Follow me on Instagram: @musicwithmegUK

Leave me a comment below if you have any questions!

videos.title: All About the Alto Clef
videos.description:
In this video we will learn about the Alto Clef - what it's used for, how to easily read notes, and how it compares to other clefs. We'll also learn how to easily switch music between the treble and alto clefs. Now all that's left is to practice!

Find theory resources on Ko-fi! ko-fi.com/musicwithmeg
Follow me on Instagram: @musicwithmegUK

Leave me a comment below if you have any questions!

videos.title: Simple and Compound Time | Grade 5 Theory
videos.description:
In today's video we're learning about Simple and Compound Time Signatures!
It's important to understand the difference in these time signatures to help you count bars, keep in time, and place the beats correctly!
You'll need to know Simple and Compound time signatures for Grade 5 Theory.

Find theory resources on Ko-fi! ko-fi.com/musicwithmeg
Follow me on Instagram: @musicwithmegUK

Leave me a comment below if you have any questions!

videos.title: Vampire | Olivia Rodrigo | Easy Violin Tutorial
videos.description:
Violin School Returns! With something a little bit different....

This week, we're learning Meg's easy violin arrangement of Vampire by Olivia Rodrigo. This tune is super expressive on the violin, and with a little practice, you'll be wowing your friends in no time!!

Download the sheet music from my Ko-fi page: 
www.ko-fi.com/musicwithmeg

If you enjoyed this tutorial, be sure to give it a Thumbs Up, and leave me a comment letting me know what you'd like to learn next!

Happy practicing!
Meg x

videos.title: Irregular Time Signatures | Grade 5 Theory
videos.description:
Today we are learning about Irregular Time Signatures!
It's easier than you think to identify these time signatures, and once you understand how to group the beats, it's a doddle to write and play music in these time signatures!
You'll need to understand how to group notes and beats in irregular time signatures for Grade 5 Theory!
